**Delloreese Patricia Early** (July 6, 1931 – November 19, 2017), known
professionally as **Della Reese** , was an American jazz and gospel singer,
actress, and [ordained minister](/wiki/Minister_\(Christianity\) "Minister
\(Christianity\)") whose career spanned seven decades. Reese's long career
began as a singer, scoring a hit with her 1959 single "[Don't You
Know?](/wiki/Don%27t_You_Know%3F "Don't You Know?")". In the late–1960s, Reese
hosted her own talk show, _Della_ , which ran for 197 episodes.[1][2] She also
starred in films beginning in 1975, including playing opposite [Redd
Foxx](/wiki/Redd_Foxx "Redd Foxx") in _[Harlem Nights](/wiki/Harlem_Nights
"Harlem Nights")_ (1989), [Martin Lawrence](/wiki/Martin_Lawrence "Martin
Lawrence") in _[A Thin Line Between Love and
Hate](/wiki/A_Thin_Line_Between_Love_and_Hate "A Thin Line Between Love and
Hate")_ (1996) and [Elliott Gould](/wiki/Elliott_Gould "Elliott Gould") in
_[Expecting Mary](/wiki/Expecting_Mary "Expecting Mary")_ (2010). She achieved
continuing success in the television religious supernatural
[drama](/wiki/Drama_\(film_and_television\) "Drama \(film and television\)")
_[Touched by an Angel](/wiki/Touched_by_an_Angel "Touched by an Angel")_
(1994–2003), in which Reese played the leading role of Tess.

## Early years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early years")]

Della Reese was born **Delloreese Patricia Early** on July 6, 1931, in the
historic [Black Bottom](/wiki/Black_Bottom,_Detroit "Black Bottom, Detroit")
neighborhood of Detroit, Michigan, to Richard Thaddeus Early, an African
American steelworker, and Nellie (Mitchelle), a Native American cook of the
[Cherokee](/wiki/Cherokee "Cherokee") tribe.[3][4][5] Her mother had had
several children before Reese's birth, none of whom lived with her; hence,
Reese grew up as an only child. At six years old, Reese began singing in
church. From this experience, she became an avid [gospel](/wiki/Gospel_music
"Gospel music") singer. On weekends in the 1940s, she and her mother would go
to the movies independently to watch the likes of [Joan
Crawford](/wiki/Joan_Crawford "Joan Crawford"), [Bette
Davis](/wiki/Bette_Davis "Bette Davis"), and [Lena Horne](/wiki/Lena_Horne
"Lena Horne") portray glamorous lives on screen. Afterwards, Reese would act
out the scenes from the films. In 1944, she began her career directing the
young people's choir, after she had nurtured acting plus her obvious musical
talent. She was often chosen, on radio, as a regular singer. At the age of 13,
she was hired to sing with [Mahalia Jackson](/wiki/Mahalia_Jackson "Mahalia
Jackson")'s gospel group. Delloreese entered Detroit's popular [Cass Technical
High School](/wiki/Cass_Technical_High_School "Cass Technical High School")
(where she attended the same year as Edna Rae Gillooly, later known as [Ellen
Burstyn](/wiki/Ellen_Burstyn "Ellen Burstyn")). She also continued with her
touring with Jackson. With higher grades, she was the first in her family to
graduate from high school in 1947, at only 15.

Afterwards, she formed her own gospel group, the [Meditation
Singers](/wiki/Meditation_Singers "Meditation Singers"). However, due in part
to the death of her mother and her father's serious illness, Reese had to
interrupt her schooling at [Wayne State
University](/wiki/Wayne_State_University "Wayne State University") to help
support her family. Faithful to the memory of her mother, Delloreese moved out
of her father's house when she disapproved of him taking up with a new
girlfriend. She then took on odd jobs, such as truck driver, dental
receptionist, and elevator operator, after 1949. Performing in clubs, Early
soon decided to shorten her name from "Delloreese Early" to "Della Reese".

## Musical career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Musical career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(November 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Della_Reese_Jubilee_Records.jpg/120px-
Della_Reese_Jubilee_Records.jpg)](/wiki/File:Della_Reese_Jubilee_Records.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Della_Reese_Jubilee_Records.jpg "Enlarge")

Reese, circa 1961.

Reese was discovered by the gospel singer [Mahalia
Jackson](/wiki/Mahalia_Jackson "Mahalia Jackson"), and her big break came when
she won a contest, which gave her a week to sing at Detroit's well-known Flame
Show Bar. Reese remained there for eight weeks. Although her roots were in
[gospel music](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel music"), she now was being exposed
to and influenced by such [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") artists as [Ella
Fitzgerald](/wiki/Ella_Fitzgerald "Ella Fitzgerald"), [Sarah
Vaughan](/wiki/Sarah_Vaughan "Sarah Vaughan") and [Billie
Holiday](/wiki/Billie_Holiday "Billie Holiday"). In 1953, she signed a
recording contract with [Jubilee Records](/wiki/Jubilee_Records "Jubilee
Records"), for which she recorded six albums. Later that year, she also joined
the [Hawkins](/wiki/Erskine_Hawkins "Erskine Hawkins") Orchestra. Her first
recordings for Jubilee were songs such as "[In the Still of the
Night](/wiki/In_the_Still_of_the_Night_\(Cole_Porter_song\) "In the Still of
the Night \(Cole Porter song\)")" (originally published in 1937), "[I've Got
My Love to Keep Me Warm](/wiki/I%27ve_Got_My_Love_to_Keep_Me_Warm "I've Got My
Love to Keep Me Warm")" and "[Time After
Time](/wiki/Time_After_Time_\(1947_song\) "Time After Time \(1947 song\)")"
(1947). The songs were later included on the album _And That Reminds Me_
(1959).

In 1957, Reese released a single called "[And That Reminds
Me](/wiki/And_That_Reminds_Me "And That Reminds Me")". After years of
performing, she gained chart success with this song. It became a Top Twenty
pop hit and a million-seller record. That year, Reese was voted by
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ ,
_[Cashbox](/wiki/Cashbox_\(magazine\) "Cashbox \(magazine\)")_ and various
other magazines, as "The Most Promising Singer". In 1959, Reese moved to [RCA
Records](/wiki/RCA_Records "RCA Records") and released her first RCA single,
called "[Don't You Know?](/wiki/Don%27t_You_Know%3F "Don't You Know?")," which
was adapted from [Giacomo Puccini](/wiki/Giacomo_Puccini "Giacomo Puccini")'s
music for _[La bohème](/wiki/La_boh%C3%A8me "La bohème"),_ specifically, the
aria "[Quando m'en vo'](/wiki/Quando_m%27en_vo%27 "Quando m'en vo'")"
(Musetta's Waltz). It became her biggest hit to date, reaching the number 2
spot on the pop charts and topping the [R&B](/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues "Rhythm
and blues") charts (then called the "Hot R&B Sides") that year. It sold over
one million copies, and was awarded a [gold
disc](/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification "Music recording sales
certification") by the [RIAA](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America
"Recording Industry Association of America").[6] Eventually, the song came to
be widely considered the [signature song](/wiki/List_of_signature_songs "List
of signature songs") of her early career. She then released a successful
follow-up single called "Not One Minute More" (number 16). She remained on the
[_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") chart with
"And Now" (number 69). In 1960 she released "[Someday (You'll Want Me to Want
You)](/wiki/Someday_\(You%27ll_Want_Me_to_Want_You\) "Someday \(You'll Want Me
to Want You\)")" (number 56) which was drawn from her Grammy-nominated album
_[Della](/wiki/Della_\(album\) "Della \(album\)")_. The album rose in the pop
album charts to number 35.

In November 1960, Reese appeared in advertisements in
_[Ebony](/wiki/Ebony_\(magazine\) "Ebony \(magazine\)")_ magazine for the
newly launched AMI Continental [jukebox](/wiki/Jukebox "Jukebox"). Reese
recorded regularly throughout the 1960s, releasing singles and several albums.
Two of the most significant were _[The Classic Della](/wiki/The_Classic_Della
"The Classic Della")_ (1962) and _Waltz with Me, Della_ (1963), which
broadened her fan base internationally. She recorded several jazz-focused
albums, including _Della Reese Live_ (1966), _On Strings of Blue_ (1967) and
_One of a Kind_ (1978). She also performed in [Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las
Vegas") for nine years and toured across the country. Reese continued to
record albums in the following decades, receiving two more Grammy nominations
in the gospel category for the album _Della Reese and Brilliance_ (1991) and
for the live recorded album, _My Soul Feels Better Right Now_ (1999).[7]
Motown singer [Martha Reeves](/wiki/Martha_Reeves "Martha Reeves") cites Reese
as a major influence and says she named her group [The
Vandellas](/wiki/Martha_and_the_Vandellas "Martha and the Vandellas") after
Van Dyke Street in Detroit and Della Reese.

## Television and film
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Television and film career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Della_Reese_1977.JPG/180px-
Della_Reese_1977.JPG)](/wiki/File:Della_Reese_1977.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Della_Reese_1977.JPG "Enlarge")

Reese appearing in a [Kraft Foods](/wiki/Kraft_Foods "Kraft Foods")
commercial, 1977.

In 1969, Reese began a transition into acting work which would eventually lead
to her highest profile. Her first attempt at television stardom was a talk
show series, _Della_ , which was cancelled after 197 episodes (June 9, 1969 –
March 13, 1970).[8] In 1970, Reese became the first black woman to guest host
_[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny
Carson](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Johnny_Carson "The Tonight Show
Starring Johnny Carson")_. She appeared in several TV movies and miniseries,
was a regular on _[Chico and the Man](/wiki/Chico_and_the_Man "Chico and the
Man")_ and played the mother of [B. A. Baracus](/wiki/B._A._Baracus "B. A.
Baracus") in _[The A-Team](/wiki/The_A-Team "The A-Team")_ episode "Lease with
an Option to Die". In 1991, she starred opposite her old friend Redd Foxx in
his final sitcom, _[The Royal Family](/wiki/The_Royal_Family_\(TV_series\)
"The Royal Family \(TV series\)"),_ but his death halted production of the
series for several months. Reese also did [voice-over](/wiki/Voice-over
"Voice-over") for the late 1980s Hanna-Barbera animated series _[A Pup Named
Scooby-Doo](/wiki/A_Pup_Named_Scooby-Doo "A Pup Named Scooby-Doo")_ on ABC. In
1989, she starred alongside [Eddie Murphy](/wiki/Eddie_Murphy "Eddie Murphy"),
[Richard Pryor](/wiki/Richard_Pryor "Richard Pryor") and [Redd
Foxx](/wiki/Redd_Foxx "Redd Foxx") in the film _[Harlem
Nights](/wiki/Harlem_Nights "Harlem Nights"),_ in which she performed a fight
scene with Eddie Murphy. Reese appeared as a panelist on several episodes of
the popular television game show _[Match Game](/wiki/Match_Game "Match
Game")._

### Television guest
appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Television guest appearances")]

Reese has had a wide variety of guest-starring roles, beginning with an
episode of _[The Mod Squad](/wiki/The_Mod_Squad "The Mod Squad")._ This led to
other roles in such series as: _[The Bold Ones: The New
Doctors](/wiki/The_Bold_Ones:_The_New_Doctors "The Bold Ones: The New
Doctors"),_ _Getting Together,_ _[Police
Woman](/wiki/Police_Woman_\(TV_series\) "Police Woman \(TV series\)"),_
_[Petrocelli](/wiki/Petrocelli "Petrocelli"),_ _Joe Forrester,_ _[Police
Story](/wiki/Police_Story_\(1973_TV_series\) "Police Story \(1973 TV
series\)"),_ _[The Rookies](/wiki/The_Rookies "The Rookies"),_
_[McCloud](/wiki/McCloud_\(TV_series\) "McCloud \(TV series\)"),_ _[Sanford
and Son](/wiki/Sanford_and_Son "Sanford and Son")_ with old friend [Redd
Foxx](/wiki/Redd_Foxx "Redd Foxx"), _[Vega$](/wiki/Vegas_\(1978_TV_series\)
"Vegas \(1978 TV series\)"),_ _[Insight](/wiki/Insight_\(TV_series\) "Insight
\(TV series\)")_ and two episodes of _[The Love Boat](/wiki/The_Love_Boat "The
Love Boat")._ She also had a recurring role on _It Takes Two_ opposite
[Richard Crenna](/wiki/Richard_Crenna "Richard Crenna") and [Patty
Duke](/wiki/Patty_Duke "Patty Duke"), three episodes of _[Crazy Like a
Fox](/wiki/Crazy_Like_a_Fox_\(TV_series\) "Crazy Like a Fox \(TV series\)"),_
four episodes of _[Charlie& Co.](/wiki/Charlie_%26_Co. "Charlie & Co.")_
opposite [Flip Wilson](/wiki/Flip_Wilson "Flip Wilson"),
_[227](/wiki/227_\(TV_series\) "227 \(TV series\)")_ with best friend [Marla
Gibbs](/wiki/Marla_Gibbs "Marla Gibbs"), _[MacGyver](/wiki/MacGyver
"MacGyver"),_ _[Night Court](/wiki/Night_Court "Night Court"),_ _[Dream
On](/wiki/Dream_On_\(TV_series\) "Dream On \(TV series\)"),_ _[Designing
Women](/wiki/Designing_Women "Designing Women"),_ _[Picket
Fences](/wiki/Picket_Fences "Picket Fences"),_ [Disney
Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney Channel")'s _[That's So
Raven](/wiki/That%27s_So_Raven "That's So Raven")_ and _[The Young and the
Restless](/wiki/The_Young_and_the_Restless "The Young and the Restless")._

### _Touched by an
Angel_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Touched by an Angel")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(November 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
After coping with the death of one of her best friends, [Redd
Foxx](/wiki/Redd_Foxx "Redd Foxx"), in 1991, she was reluctant to play an
older female lead in the inspirational television drama _[Touched by an
Angel](/wiki/Touched_by_an_Angel "Touched by an Angel"),_ but went ahead and
auditioned for the role of Tess. She wanted to have a one-shot agreement
between [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") and producer [Martha
Williamson](/wiki/Martha_Williamson "Martha Williamson"), but ordered more
episodes. Reese was widely seen as a key component of the show's success.
Already starring on _Touched by an Angel_ was the lesser-known
[Irish](/wiki/Irish_people "Irish people") actress [Roma
Downey](/wiki/Roma_Downey "Roma Downey"), who played the role of case worker
Tess's angel/employee, Monica. In numerous interviews, there was an on- and
off-screen chemistry between both Reese and Downey. The character of Tess was
the angelic supervisor who sent the other angels out on missions to help
people redeem their lives and show them God's love, while at the same time,
she was sassy and had a no-nonsense attitude. The show often featured a
climactic monologue delivered by the angel Monica in which she reveals herself
as an angel to a human with the words: "I am an angel sent by God to tell you
that He loves you." The character of Tess was portrayed by Reese as down-to-
earth, experienced and direct. Reese also sang the show's theme song, "Walk
with You", and was featured prominently on the soundtrack album produced in
conjunction with the show.

During its first season in 1994, many critics were skeptical about the show,
it being the second overtly religious prime-time fantasy series, after
_[Highway to Heaven](/wiki/Highway_to_Heaven "Highway to Heaven")._ The show
had a rocky start, low ratings and was cancelled 11 episodes into the first
season. However, with the help of a massive letter-writing campaign, the show
was resuscitated the following season and became a huge ratings winner for the
next seven seasons. At the beginning of the fourth season in 1997, Reese
threatened to leave the show because she was making less than her co-stars;
CBS ended up raising her salary. _Touched by an Angel_ was cancelled in 2003,
but it continued re-running heavily in syndication and on [Ion
Television](/wiki/Ion_Television "Ion Television") (formerly PAX-TV), [The
Hallmark Channel](/wiki/Hallmark_Channel "Hallmark Channel"),
[Up](/wiki/Up_\(TV_channel\) "Up \(TV channel\)"), and later [MeTV](/wiki/MeTV
"MeTV"). Roma Downey said of her on- and off-screen relationship with Reese:

“ | She's very wise. She's very loving. She can be a little gruff at times, but she's always adoring and adorable. I lost my mother when I was very young, and during my whole adolescence and into my twenties, I'd been looking for a mother figure, and I really think I can say with absolute truth and sincerity that I feel that I finally found her in Della Reese. | ”  
---|---|---  
  
Downey later also said:

“ | I think I'll just always remember the feel of her neck against my cheek when she hugs me and the love I know that she has for me and the love that I feel for her and the love that she has for God. To know Della is to know that she loves God. | ”  
---|---|---  
  
## Personal life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Personal life")]

In 2005, Reese was honored by [Oprah Winfrey](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey "Oprah
Winfrey") at her Legends Ball ceremony, along with 25 other black
women.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] On July 6, 2011, Reese celebrated her 80th birthday at the Catalina
Jazz Club in [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles").[9] In 2015, a
Golden Palm Star on the [Palm Springs](/wiki/Palm_Springs,_California "Palm
Springs, California") [Walk of Stars](/wiki/Palm_Springs_Walk_of_Stars "Palm
Springs Walk of Stars") was dedicated to her.[10] Della Reese was the
godmother of Roma Downey's daughter Reilly Marie. Reese officiated at[11] the
marriage ceremony of [Roma Downey](/wiki/Roma_Downey "Roma Downey") and [Mark
Burnett](/wiki/Mark_Burnett "Mark Burnett") in the absence of Downey's late
mother.

### Family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Family")]

Reese's mother, Nellie Mitchelle Early, died in 1949 of an [intracerebral
hemorrhage](/wiki/Intracerebral_hemorrhage "Intracerebral hemorrhage").
Reese's father, Richard Early, died ten years later. Reese had an adoptive
daughter whom she acquired from a family member unable to care for her, named
Delorese Daniels Owens, in 1961. Owens died on March 14, 2002. She passed away
from complications stemming from [pituitary disease](/wiki/Pituitary_disease
"Pituitary disease"). Reese said about the painful experience, sharing her
frustration with the lack of awareness and knowledge of pituitary disorders:

“ | When it happened, I thought, 'It's such an odd thing to die from,' because pituitary problems aren't something you hear about. It makes it harder because you don't understand what happened. It seemed so strange and hard to explain. It still is, to be honest.[12] | ”  
---|---|---  
  
### Marriages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Marriages")]

In 1952, Reese married factory worker Vermont Adolphus Bon Taliaferro,
nineteen years her senior,[13] and adopted the stage name Pat Ferro[14] for a
week, before introducing the stage name she used for the rest of her life –
though sources differ as to whether this was after the failure of the
marriage,[13] or simply a show-business decision.[15] A second marriage
ceremony, on December 28, 1959, to accountant Leroy Basil Gray, who had two
children by a previous marriage, was kept secret for some time.[16] This
marriage either ended in divorce[17] or was annulled on the basis that Gray's
previous divorce was invalid.[13] Reese appears to have been briefly married
to [Mercer Ellington](/wiki/Mercer_Ellington "Mercer Ellington") (who was then
her manager) in 1961, before this was annulled later that year due to
Ellington's [Mexican divorce](/wiki/Mexican_divorce "Mexican divorce") being
ruled invalid.[13]In 1983, she married Franklin Thomas Lett, Jr., a concert
producer and writer.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Health")]

In 1979, after taping a guest spot for _[The Tonight
Show](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Johnny_Carson "The Tonight Show Starring
Johnny Carson"),_ she suffered a near-fatal brain [aneurysm](/wiki/Aneurysm
"Aneurysm"), but made a full recovery after two surgeries by neurosurgeon
[Charles Drake](/wiki/Charles_George_Drake "Charles George Drake") at
[University Hospital](/wiki/University_Hospital_\(London,_Ontario\)
"University Hospital \(London, Ontario\)") in [London,
Ontario](/wiki/London,_Ontario "London, Ontario").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
2016, shortly after her 85th birthday, Reese was said to be in poor health,
and had undergone multiple surgeries. She further disclosed that she had
neglected her health for years, which had contributed to her developing
diabetes.[18] After her last appearance on _[Signed, Sealed,
Delivered](/wiki/Signed,_Sealed,_Delivered_\(TV_series\) "Signed, Sealed,
Delivered \(TV series\)")_ , she had retired from acting. While Reese
sometimes used a wheelchair, she avoided using one often, because it would
make her condition worse.[19]

### Ministry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Ministry")]

In the 1980s, Reese was ordained as a
[minister](/wiki/Minister_\(Christianity\) "Minister \(Christianity\)")
through the Christian New Thought branch known as Unity, after serving as the
senior minister and founder of her own church, Understanding Principles for
Better Living.[20] The "Up Church" is under Universal Foundation for Better
Living, a denomination of Christian New Thought founded by Rev. [Johnnie
Colemon](/wiki/Johnnie_Colemon "Johnnie Colemon"), a close friend of Rev.
Reese-Lett. As of
2009[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit),
they meet at First Lutheran Church in [Inglewood,
California](/wiki/Inglewood,_California "Inglewood, California").[21] In her
ministerial work, she was known as the Rev. Dr. Della Reese Lett.[22]

## Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Della_Reese&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Death")]

Reese died on November 19, 2017, at her Los Angeles, California, home at the
age of 86. No cause was given, although she had suffered from Type
2-diabetes.[23].[24] Her representative Lynda Blensky told _[USA
Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_ , "We lost a magnificent woman who was a
trailblazer in many ways."[25]

Longtime friends [Roma Downey](/wiki/Roma_Downey "Roma Downey") (with whom she
worked on _Touched by an Angel_) and [Jackee Harry](/wiki/Jackee_Harry "Jackee
Harry") (with whom she worked on _227_ and _The Royal Family_) reflected on
her death. Downey said, "On behalf of her husband, Franklin Lett, and all her
friends and family, I share with you the news that our beloved Della Reese has
passed away peacefully at her California home last evening surrounded by
love," She then said: "She was an incredible wife, mother, grandmother,
friend, and pastor, as well as an award-winning actress and singer. Through
her life and work, she touched and inspired the lives of millions of people.
She was a mother to me and I had the privilege of working with her side by
side for so many years on _Touched by an Angel_. I know heaven has a brand new
angel this day. Della Reese will be forever in our hearts. Rest In Peace,
sweet angel. We love you."[26]

Harry tweeted, "I am completely devastated by the loss of Della Reese. She was
a great co-star, sparring partner, drinking buddy, and friend. She taught me
the power of prayer and the importance of humility. I'll be forever grateful
to call her my friend."[27]
